This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM AND THE SULTAN.
div.p:
To the January issue of the "Imperial and Asiatic Quarterly Review," Professor A. Vambéry contributes an important article on "PanIslamism and the Sultan of Turkey." Examining the relation between the Khalifa, or the Sultan-Khalifa, and the rest of Mohammedan rulers, he argues from historical data that the sphere of influence of the Khalifa never extended beyond the pale of purely spiritual-i.e., religious, matters; that worldly interference has been always excluded ; and, in fact, that there was no link of a closer political communication between, and still less a sign of supremacy over, the different Mohammedan countries and the Khalifa. In a word, he says, the supremacy of the Sultans of Turkey over the other princes and rulers of the Mohammedan world was always a problematic one, and never went beyond the questions touching religious matters or the relations of friendly coordinate neighbours. "Such being the case, it is really to be wondered that in the discussion which has taken place quite recently with regard to the Pan-Islamic movement, great stress should have been laid upon the Sultan
IN
ND -BOTTLES (SPLITS).
11
Table Waters."
TS OWN NATURAL GAS
AT THE NEUENAHR, GERMANY.
Khalifa's power in his capacity as a leader of the whole movement. Above all, it is well to note that this leadership is not a public but rather & clandestine one, and it is quite intelligible when the ruler of the country in such straits as Turkey, anxious to find a means of salvation, clings to a straw and exag. generates the efficiency of this his last sheet anchor. Knowing as I do the shrewdness of Sultan Abdul Hamid, I doubt whether he really has placed any confidence upon this very brittle staff, and whether the whole movement is not calculated to intimidate the insufficiently-informed Western world. If the Sultans of Turkey had the power to use their title of a Khalifa and the Pan-Islamic movement in defence against the aggression of Christian Europe, they certainly would have long ago applied it. It never occurred to their mind." On the contrary, Professor Vambéry points out, in 1857 the Sultan-Khalifa was ready to assist a Christian Power to suppress a revolution in which Mohamedans took part against their foreign ruler. But, he continues, "supposing the Sultan would continue to incite the Mohammedan subjects against their foreign ruler, his own Christian subjects would furnish ample material for a powerful retaliation, Living under a glass roof, he will twice consider before he throws stones at others. From whatever point of view we look at the question of the Sultan-Khalifa's contempla ed aspirations, we are convinced that, by toleration, justice, and liberty – the characteristic of British rule-all subversive plans of the Sultan will be easily frustrated. Even those Mohamedans who complain of alleged wrongs will take care not to fall from the frying-pan of Christian rule into the fire of Moslem tyranny and maladministration. Taken all together, it is sad and afflicting that the hitherto peaceful relation between Europe and the Moham. odan Asia has taken such a turn and has pressed upon us the discussion of this question. Not only does it aggravate the task of our standard bearers in the Moslem world, but it retards the progress and injures the fairly initiated modern life of the Mohamedans them. selves. If the younger generation of Mobamedans, anxious to propagate the war-cry of "India for the Indians," and "Egypt for the Egyptians, "fancy that their years of apprenticeship are over, and that they can already dispense with Westorn tutorship, they are grossly mistaken. The turn from an old civilisation into a modern one cannot be accomplished in a trice, and the example of Buddhistic Japan cannot stand as an encouragement for the followers of the Arabian Prophet. Of course, there is a term of the period for the latter, too. The time will come, and must come, when the Mohamedans, too, will have progressed so far as to be able to stand out their own feet; but this time has not come yet, and no sincere friend of Islem would like to see a precipitancy and hurried measures leading to disaster. It is particularly the Mohamedans in India who ought to take to heart this humble warning. They are on the best way towards & rejuvenescence of their country. They are the furthest advanced on the path of modern culture amongst their com religionists in Inner Asia, and I fully agree with Sheikh Abdul Qadir in his concluding remarks in a paper published in this "Review" (April, 1906) under the title, "Young India : its Hopes and Aspirations," when he says : "The prospect, on the whole, strikes me to be far from gloomy. There is no height which Young India may not be able to reach with wider education and a greater cooperation between the communities inhabiting the land, especially if those in whose hands God has placed our destinies give us their full sympathy, and encourage the efforts of the people to better their fortunes. Would it not be a pity to obfuscate such a promising horizon, and to endanger a bright future by adopting visionary plans which lead to darkness and ruin "

div.p: Last evening fire broke out in the house of Greek lawyer, M. Logadi, at 10, Nobar Pasbe street. It was due to the explosion of a lamp Happily the alarm was given in good time and the fire was extinguished before moo damage was done.

div.p: HM 8. Carnarvon, after spending Christma at Alexandria, sailed on her return to Malt yesterday. On Thursday, the torpedo department of the Carnarvon went through social sfo practice outside the breakwater. The firing was very fair, bits being made at 800 yards.

div.p: Several members of the Alexandria Municipal Commission are in favor of proposing that the City should create a magnificent status to its founder, Alexander the Great, on the quay, where a fine site would be chosen for a lasting memorial to the illustrious Macedonian.

Bulgarian treating a Greek in a contumacious manner. The Greek frequenters of tb oafé were very indignant at this cartoon, and tried to destroy it. div.p: This company has just declared an interim dividend for the year 1906 of 7% on both Ordinary and Deferred sbarros. The company is also paying a bonus of £l per share on the Ordinary shares of £1 each (resulting from the subdivision of the £5 abares), Boob payment being in the discharge of the bonus provided for by the articles of association.
The capital of the company now our sisters of 800,000 shares of £l each without destination of ola B. Certificates for shares are now in preparation and will shortly be engaged.

div.head: LAND VALUES AND MORTGAGES.
div.p: A leading firm of bankers base supplied as with the following information in respect to land mortgages in Egypt, which, the booming from such a reliable source, may be accepted as correct and will be read with interest.

They are of the opinion that the total amount of money lent on mortgages on agricultural lands in Egypt does not exceed forty millions of pounds, whereas they consider that the value of the total area under cultivation can be safely pat at a minimum of four hundred millions of pounds so that the outstanding loans are only about ten per cent of the actual value,-a position which cannot be found in any other covantry in the world,

div.head: THE "COMPTOIR."
div.p: The board of directors of the Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte met yesterday evening at the bead offices of the company at Alexandria. The date of the subscription of the new i88de of twenty-five thousand shares was settled to take place on the 15th and 16th proxy. Of the issue price, which is £6, £2, after the expenses connected with the i88le have been redacted, will go towards the reserve food. The board then discussed the question of doubling the company's hospital, which in that case will amount to £1,000,000. After a careful study of the question it was decided to submit it to the consideration of the next general meeting, which is to be held on the 16th proxy.
We understand that the Founders' shares will be treated in fractions of one-tenth about the middle of next month.

In reference to the proposed doubling of the company's capital, it is proposed only to ask for permission to be granted to the scheme at the meeting on the 16th prozo. It is not to be understood that the board will at once proceed to raise the capital to that som immediately afterwards.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: The Legislative Connolly, which met on Thursday, under the presidency of Abdel, Hamid Pasba Sadek, had two subjects under

consideration, i.e., the regulations recently framed by the Ministry of Justice in regard to public security in the Western desert, and the report of the commission appointed by the Council to study the organisation of the ghafir service. With regard to the former, the Council
decided to have the regulations printed so that Tesol member might have an opportunity of
making himself acquainted with the scheme. As to the question of the ghafir service, the Council decided to ask the Ministry of the
laterior for a copy of the regulation it had I promised to draw op for the ghaffire, and the
question will be discussed on receipt of these.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "LOHENGRIN."

It has long seemed to use more than doubtful to what extent sore performances should be given which merit and receive the universal verdict of 'very predictable, considering"; and for Wagner in Italian the verdict may be taken as invariable. Trieste stands out as an example of the mingling of Teton and Latin, whole spirits Rosen ble each other no more than "Antar" and the "Morte d'Arthur." To turn to the actual : the one actor during the last two nights at the Z'zidia who would have been accepted by a northern audience was the Herald; yet we know that in Italian ears his splendid meal: low voice rang pompous and heavy. Lohengrin we found small in power, not cultivated, and his acting was consistently good: the King also (Sig. Walter Carlo) bodged himself around with an impressive majesty. Bat Elsa broke the back of the piece: ber tremolo goes near to being intolerable: in her low notes it is painful to listen to, and higher in the compass on lOAD pot but regrets the might-have-been of a fine organ. The ouroboros, male, was bad throughout, in tone, tone, and time; and the sopranos were batted a little better. The truth is, that the dignity and depth of a great German oborog can be found in Germany alone. The orchestra, which improves brightly, really rose to the occasion admirably. We congratulate Sig. Zacconi, brutagain remark that in the chorob soene he shouted to his men "aspetta" 80 lood, that had we not known that neither bride por bridegroom was in a waiting mood, bad ascribed theory to none other than Lohengrin. We hope to notice this opera again in the course of next week.
"Tosca" will be given this evening. There will be no performance on Monday, and consequently, subscribers to the "A" series will be entitled to another performance laser in the season.

div.head:
ABBAS THEATRE.
A TRIPLE BILL
div.p: The Abbas Theatre is filling up the interval between Mlle. Brandes and the arrival of an opera troupe with various French players. Last night three pieces were given, "Son Pothead," "Leora Pilles," and "L'Outrage." ToDigbt the "Maitre des Forges" will be attempted. The three short plays I mention are pot very wonderful either in construction or in the matter, they are simply scenes of lower life: the courtesan, the space, the course of private rooms, and her convent bred daughter who follows in her mother's footsteps - with her mother's lover! And, last of all, most sordid, and yet not without power, the fate of the innocent girl who is arrested with others of a class known to her: the formalities, which are nothing to them, are death to her. Mme. Lindey appeared in the first and last of these pieces. One can hardly judge the number of these, except that she was excellent in the first and realistic in the last. It was rather terrible to see how those phases of life at which most of Paris would smile are a horror and madness to those whom it should respect. The rest of the actors and actresses were distinctly good, especially Mme. Andrieux and M. Displays. Bat before one can find their strength, or the distinctive note of Mme. Lindsey herself, one must see some longer play in wish more than one phase is brought to light. The "Maitre des Forges" will serve ; and comparison --if it is | possible -- with Jane Hadiog's rendering will be interesting

"LE MAÎTRE DE FORGES." Alas! poor Ohnet! All his Barrey side Berrios appeared, bald and unconvincing, last night His melodrama was given well, very well, but given in itself without the touch of magic that veiled it, induced depth and life into it, and for moments suggested reality, onder Jane Hading's ipfi 1000e. One can make comparison all through in a certain sense, and especially in the lesser parts : these were just as good, it not better, in the hands of the Lindy troupe. Moulinet (M. Negrel) was very good | The Dake was even better than M. Hauterive M. Salvator and Mme. Lindey herself brought out the total note of the play. They were both excellent, admirable in many places: their third and fourth act showed real talent and feeling, but it was all Ohnet without those moments where personality swamped criticism We looked on, was did not feel it was a performance, not a memory, flattering to the actors, but photographic of the author whom Jane Hading idealized. There was hardly anyone in the house: people bere evidently only going to pass the time and not with many ideas of seeing plays. It needs a Hading, Brandès, or, more suitable because more pronounced, an Escalais to rouse them.

div.head:
RACING AT HELOUAN.
FIRST WINTER MEETING,
div.p: In spite of the genial weather, there was not A crowded attendance at the first Winter Meeting at Helosan, and the ladies were in a very small minority. Mrs. Wyone and her friend, Miss Blythe, were present, the former looking little the worse for her motor accident of Thursday, which might have been a very serious affair. Her only injuries seem ta have been a few small scratches on the face; bat Major Wynde got severe shaking and is very much braised, being confined to his room. Illness also kept Mrs. Montagu Sommers from not only the Helouan meeting but also those of the Khedivial Sporting Club last week She has been suffering again from dengue and has bsd a touch of bronchitis as well. Mr. Montaga Summers was at Helouan, but none of his horses was running. Mr. and Mrs. Tillard was there, and Capt. and Mrs. Wilson, both looking very well and cheery; and Bo were Mrs. and Miss Nangovich and Mt. Alexandre Nangovich, little Miss Nangovich entirely harming in a glorified mushroom bat and a large flowing veil. These veils were worn by most of the ladies on the ground and were most effective and becoming. Mrs. dannders was also present: she is a newcomer to Cairo and has already a great oirole of friends. Amongst the men present were noticed Lord Rosslyn, Mr. Carter Wilson, Capt. Adams, R.B., Dr. Bentley, Mr. Michaelidos, Dr. W. Armstrong, Mr. de Costa Andrada, and many of the officers from the various regions.

The races were the most 800088stal that have ever been held in Helouan. The fields were exceptionally large, and the racing of a very big order. Some of the best horses in the country were seen out, and the finishes created a great deal of interest. It was an ideal day for racing, there is no wind or dost. Judging by the start made, it is evident that the Heloian racing season will be very societal. Prince Abbae Pasba Halim officiated as judge, assisted by Capt. Gillson. div.head: THE WEATHER IN ENGLAND.
div.p: Heavy snow storms occurred in the United Kingdom yesterday, and the telegraph lines were considerably interrupted, which has led to great delay in the transit of telegram between England and Egypt.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN ENTERPRISE IN
GREECE
div.p: The last sitting of the Greek Assize Court at Alexandria will be held on Monday next, when two chemists, Psathopoulos and Ceramides, and the professor Messari will be tried for having counterfeit diplomas of the University of Athens. This case excites a good deal of local interest as the manufacture of false University diplomas presuming to emanate from Athens was becoming a publio scandal and caused great annoyance in Greece.

div.head: GREEK ASSIZE COURT.
div.p: Mr. Constantine Meimarachi and a dom ber of Greek capitalists domiciled in Egypt have bought a large tract of lard on the Keisja road at Athens with a view to it development as a teetotal suburb of the Greek capital. The road to Kyphosis is the aristocratic promenade of Athens. The district thos acquired is to be called the "Alexandrine Sabarb."

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL.
div.p: At the extra small dance to be given at the Savoy Hotel on Tuesday next, the music will be supplied by the band of the 1st Battalion King's Own Scottish Borderers.
The Grecia Lodge of Cairo is giving their annual installation banquet at the Savoy Hotel on Wednesday next.
The medical students also give their approach banquet at the Savoy on Thursday text.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Moorish Price, with passengers | and general cargo, left Malta on the 27th inst. | and is due at Alexandria on Monday.
The Moss leper Philae sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool with general cargo including 6,464 bales of cotton.
WINDSOR HOTEL. Facing the Sea on the New Quay of Alexandria
FIRST-CLASS HOTEL. Lately Built and Furnished.
TERMS P.T. 50 PER DAY. Special terms to Government Officials.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Bark of Davraven and Lady Aileen Wyndham are arriving at Port Said shortly on their way to lodia.
The new Hellenio Diplomatic Agent and Consul General a: Cairo, M. Philoo, arrived at Alexandria from Atben: yesterday by the Khedivial Mail steamer.

M. Camille Saint Sxëne is on his way to Egypt, where will be the guest of Prince Mobamed Aly. In February, the illustrious composer goes to Monte Carin, to supervise the performances of "Timbre d'Argent."

The Rev. Patber Cotot, a rector of the Jesuits College of Paga'lah, Cairo, has left for France. He was rector for six years, and his departure will be not regretted by all who know him. He is succeeded by Père André, rector of the Jesuits of Constantinople.
The German Emperor has conferred the Cross of Chevalier of the Order of the Iron Crown on the dragoman of the German Consulate at Alexandria, M. Amin Messadié.

"Al Watau" gives the following description of Mob. Bey Farid, the friend and follower of Mustapba Pasha Kamel :-"He knows he is the son of a notable family-looks at the world de haut en bas. We are the foot passengers, be is the gentleman on the balcony. Writing to Lord Cromer, be has let his Lorde nip know that he is merely a foreign Consol, and has consequently no right to intervene in Egyptian affair.........but his character grows milder. He is less intransigeant, especially since he has learned that only genuine notables will obtain bigb posts. One fine day be may even pardon Lord Cromer for some of his peccadilloes. Meantime his one idea is the glorification of his friend Mastapba."
M. I. Seriphas, a well-known banker of Salonios, has arrived here on a business visit.

The latest arrivals at the Hôtel d'Angleterre include Sir High Bell and Miss Gertrude Bell, England ; Mr. and Mme. B1. Naville, Genova; Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Robinson, Master E. Robinson, Montreal ; Dr. Gaide Beder, Triente; Mr. P. Garnier, Mme. Pierre, Mme. L. Movisot, Mme. Migeon, Paris; Mr. and Mrs. Wm. Pierrepont Wise, London ; Miss P. Ryan, Miss Croes, England ; Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Davies, Mrs. Ring, Miss Robinson, Miss Donavon, London ; Mrs.P. R. Boxwell, Minieb; Mr. and Douglas Th. Timins ; Dr. J. Westall Anderton, Bogland.

Among the latest arrivals at the Bastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, fare Mr. J. Mezza, Mr. Grant, Mr. N. Tabet, Mr. H. Sater, Mr. and Mrs. Hanson, Mr. and Mrs. Young Son and family, Rev. J. div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Il s'est produit une légère réaction par suite de quelques liquidations. Des affaires ont eu lieu sur presque toute la côte, mais particulièrement en Comptoir.
Ce dernier monte de 8 1/16 8 1/8.
En hausse également la Privilégiée Bière d'Alexandrie de 206 à 207, l'Obligation pour celle Crédit Poucier de 271 1/2 à 372, le Trust i de 15/8 & 1 11/16 acheteurs, la Building
Lands de 5 11/16 & 6 25/38, et la Banquo d'Orient de 134 1/2 à 135.

Par contre, l'Agricole fléchit de 95/8 à 9 9/16 vendeurs, la National Bank de 28 3/8 à 28 1/4, la Ram B de 6 13/16 à 6 3/4, la Deltalight de 11 7/8 4 11 13/16, la Bébés de 42 1/2 à 42, la Filature de 13/16 à 95/32, la Cassa di Sconto de 283 1/2 à 282 1/8 l'ancienne et de 378 1/2 à 277 la nouvelle, la Banque d'Athènes de 135 1/2 à 135, l'Urbaine de 7 11/16 à 7 6/8 acheteurs, la part de fondateur Comptoir de 92 1/2 92, l'Anglo-Bg. Allotment de 3 13/16 à 3 3/4 et l'Auto-Transport de 5 1/4 à 5 vendeurs.
Le reste de la côte demeure sans changement,

Le doublement de capital, dont nous avons parlé dans notre chronique financière à propos du Comptoir, sera effectivement proposé à l'assemblée générale du 16 janvier ; mais le conseil d'administration n'a pas l'intention d'y donner suits d'ici quelque temps.

div.head:
STORMS IN EUROPE.
RAILWAY SERVICES DISORGANISE
JAPANESE LINER IN DISTRESS.

div.p: Snowstorms and gales continue to Drogba Great Britain, Germany, Austria, Switzerland, and Prague. The railway services on the Cou Dent are disorganized.

Owing to the snowstorm yesterday evening. the Japanese liner Awa Mara bound fra Antwerp for Middlesborough, was driven the rocks a mile off Rodier. Immense seas we washing over her. The liner had previous and bored, but the cable broke. The local fishing boats and a life-boat did most gallant women At midnight the two only passengers and out of a growth of 120 had been landed. The terrific gale was then threatening to prove the continuity of the work of reason and tl V88861 was heeling over.

div.head: ONLY WORK ON ANGLO-EGYPTIAN SUDAN. REISSUE JUST OUT.
div.p: CONTAINING An Geographical Map of the whole Nile Basin
OUR SUDAN.
By JOHN WARD, F.8.A. AUTHOR OF "EGYPT, ITS PYRAMIDS AND PROGRESS."

p.hi: Dedicated by request to LORD KITCHENER OF KHARTOUM. Crown 4to. 400 pp. 720 Illustrations

div.p: Prior 210. not, A Now Issue has been found necessary
within Six Months.
Letter from Sir Rudolph von Slatin

Dear Mr Ward,- Your delightful and most interesting book on the Sudan has reached me I congratulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. All of us who have done our little best to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands... I don't suppose anyone releases more than I do the orange that has some over the Sadan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disappeared from the NOODO. Your description of the 'Peace and Progress' if, in fact, a sequel to my 'Fire and Sword in the Sudan.' With kindest regards, believe me,
Yours sincerely,
RUDOLF V. SLATIN.

div.head: YACOUB PASHA ARTIN.
div.p: MR. DICEY'S TRIBUTE
ng
on
Mc. Elward Dicey, writing in the "Dai Telegraph," gives the following account of the reasons for the departure of Yacon Pa. Artin trom poklic life: -

For the last thirty-odd years the Ministry of Education has been in the hands of Yahoo Pasba Artin. This gentleman, a man of great ability, big character, an Armenian by race but born in Egypt, is esteemed by every visit of eminence who is interested in historical, philological, or antiquarian studies, and from his extraordinary knowledge of foreign languages could converse fluently in English, French German, 48 well as Arabic, Turkish, at Persian. Barley this year, without his being even consulted, an English official of no educational experience, and young enough to Atria Pasha's son, was appointed Ad coadjutor, and in fact, it not in Dame, as b superior in his uw office. Naturally Art tendered his resignation, on the ground of advancing years, but was requested to bold over for the present. On the return of the Court and the leading British officials attire to summer holidays, Martin received a note a car in his unofficial resignation, and shortly afterwards it was announced that Saad Pael Zaghloul had been appointed as Minister of Public Instruction in his place. I am informed this gentleman is a man of great learning a high legal ability, and that he is personal well fitted for the new post, though without any of the singular authority which his predecessor possessed in virtue of his exceptional reputation. The salary allotted to this newcomer te exceeds that enjɔyed by Artin Pasha. To various parts of the story is that Saad Pash Zaghlool is one of the most distinguished Mastaphs Pasba Kamel's adherents, and to an active part in the latter's some for raisin by public description a some sufficient to foon a university in Cairo to impart higher education under Mohammedan teachers. For man obvie26-and, as I think, just-reasons to the establishment of such a stronghold of Islam in Egypt is not regarded with favor by our Be tied authorities, and therefore it may have been politico to deprive "Young Egypt" of is a most influential member by appointing bim t * very collaborative post. This is the only plausible explanation of Artin being dismissed and replaced by Zaghloul, bat I cannot answer for it correctness

div.head: TRADE AT RED SEA PORTS
div.p: r

Manchester shippers who boy for the E. Coast of Africa and the Red Sea ports give bu moderate accounts of the sales of the various classes of textiles that usually go to the market. The comparative dalness in cotto
branch is, the "Manchester Guardian" says is probably due to some extent to the compet
tion of the Indian mills. The present Bomba
shipments not only include the general court 3) counts of yarn and low makes of the grey

image, but also an increasing quantity of the fine grades of cloth that was until quite recently shipped from Manchester. Lancashire make of 36in. 30 yard shootings in 10 and 12 ree are, however, in fair demand, principally fa

Zanzibar and Mombasa. The trading towns on | the Red Sea are now moderate customers to this style of cloth, which may be attributed to the solarcity and dearness of the American 'cobots," which usually have a large sale at Jeddah and Hodeidah. In the Abyssinia market, English and American shootings have now to compete with Italian makes, which are shipped through Genoa to the African colonies. The Italian "Cabot" somewhat resembles the better qualities sent from the United States, being made in the Americas style with "twist-way" weft. Though comparatively cheap these goods have a "reedy" ad rugby appearance and are not likely for some time to come to interfere considerably with the sales of the softer spun Baglish maker, or to well-made and well-finished American goods.

div.head: APPARENTLY INCURABLE.
div.p: SAVED BY DOAN's BACKACHE KIDNEY Pills.

Mr. Edward Greed, Mildmay Park Wesleyan Chorob, London, England, wrote: "Dear Sirs After what I have been through, I can feel of everyone who suffers from kidney complaint Your medicine has made me feel quite another man, and I am able to work harder today than I have done for years before.

"The first symptom of my kidney trouble which began about six years ago, was a chilly feeling in the back, like cold water rapping down me. It did not appear to be very serious until about nine months ago when something seemed to be forming in the passages. I then became so ill that I had to go into hospital. where I was operated upon by Dr. - After the operation, I went to Hastings to try to pick up my strength, but in vain, and I could never seem to get rid of the pain in the loin.
I grew helpless, and could not sleep at night on the day. I would fairly groan with the pain.
I do not know what I should have done if I - bad not heard of Doan's Backache Kidney • Pills, for they have been a great boon to me.
Believe me, yours sincerely, (ei goed) EDWARD GREEN."
Over a year later, Mr. Green wrote again "I may say that, although I am still a firm believer in God's Backache. Kidney Pills, I have
left off using them simply be use I never - suffer now from my old troubles. I enjoy the
best of health, and do a hard day's work with any man---that speaks well for Doan's Pille."
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE
div.p: La semaine qui vient de 6 sir de compren que trois séano 38 à 030se des fêtes de Noi qui ont en lien. Il en sera de même la semain prochaine à l'occasion du Jour de l'Av. Rie d'ailleurs de bien saillant sur notre place, sinon la hausse de la Cassa di Sconto et da Comptoir Pidancier et Commercial, dont nous donnon plus loin les motifs.

Au Caire, la Bourse Khédiviale s'est effor durée de 15) aux environs de 110 livres, tandi que les Entreprises Immobilières et de Travail entsteint 80 livres pour finir à 18 1/2. Les Ba press Nile Steamers ont également bénéficié d'une forte avance à 6 1/2, par o'turer aux environs de 5 7/8. Quant au Comptoir et à la Case di sotto, ils ont gago é respectivement me de mi-livre ; la part de fondateur Comptoir a fait un bond énorme de 70 livres e92 1/2. A pote encore une hausse de 5/16 sur ta Building Lands, de 1/2 livre pour la Nile Land, de 7/ sur les Nangovich et de 1 3/4 sur la Bebera aidai qu'une baisse de 1/4 de livre sur le Publications Égyptiennes.

Le Conseil d'administration de Comptoir Papier et Commercial, réuni le soir Siège social à Alexandrie, a fixé au 15 at 11 janvier prochain la Boa sorption aux 86,001 actions nouvelles, autorisée par la dernière assemblée générale. Bor le prix d'émission qui est de six livres, deux livres, de luation
fuite des frais d'émission, iront à la réserve * L3 Conseil a ensuite examiné l'opportunité

d'un doublement du capital social, qui atteindrait ainsi 1 million de livres. Après op étude approfondie de la question, il a oid de la soumettre à la prochaine assemblée générale, convoqués pour le 16 janvier. Parigo nons en somme: ear ce chapitre, ajoutant que nous croyons savoir qu'on commencera à traiter en dixiè nes les parts de fondateur Comptoir vers la mi janvier.

La Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio a décidé de porter son capital de 10 millions & 15 millions de tarnos par l'émission de 50,00) action nouvelles de 100 francs à 150 francs. Les 51 francs de prime seront portés à la réserve. L! Souscription est réservée aux anciens portent dans la proportion d'une action nouvelle contrib deux anciennes. La date de l'émission n'est pas encore fixée d'une manière définitive, mai
il est vraisemblable qu'elle aura lieu da 1! - janvier au 15 février prochain. On estime que
le coupon sera cette année de 15% sor lo valeur nominale; il a été l'année passée de 11%

L'assemblée de la Salt & Soda tenue bien an Caire & approuvé les comptes et le bilan aide que la proposition du conseil fixant ar dividende de 7 1/2 %, soit 1 ch. 6 people pal action. Le rachat des 1 000 parte de fondatea et leur remplacement par 50.000 actions ordinaires, dont 30.000 seront émises de suite et 20.000 ultérieurement, ont été également ratifiés.

Le conseil d'administration de la Societe d'Entreprises Urbaines et Rurales a fixé au 9 et 11 janvier prochain l'émission des 25.000 actions nouvelles de £4£ 6, autorisée par les statuts. La prime de £ 2 sera portée à la réserve et la souscription réservée aux porteurs de 75.000 actions actuelles.

L'assemblée générale des actionnaires de l'Alexandria and Ramlah Railway Co., Ltd., en lieu bier au siège social. Les recettes, y compris le solde du précédent exercice et diver profit, atteignent L.B 64 694. Les dépenser D'ayant été que de LB.37.028, il reste un bénéfice de L. B.27.571 qui sera réparti de façon suivante : 1° LE 22.790 de dividende aux actionnaires, soit 213% on shelling 8 4/3 par action de £ 1 nominale ; %° L.B.4.000 au fond de renouvellement ; 3° L.E 500 de gratifications à l'x employés méritants ; 4° le solde, soit L-E. 280, à reporter. Il a été créé à fonds de renouvellement par d98 pred vements partiels sur les bénéfices de chaque année pour éviter les difficultés qui por taient se pré-monté lorsqu'il faudra, dan un avenir plus ou moins lointain, procéder on renouvellement important de matériel. B comparant les résultats de l'exercice avec cu de l'année précédente, les astiondaires ont toa lieu d'être satisfaits; on voit, en effet, par le chiffres donnés ci-dessus, que 'les recettes ont augmenté de L. E. 11.866, tandis que le dépense8 De se sont accrues que de L. B. 3.413 laissant ainsi un surplus de bénéfices de LE 8 452. Le coefficient d'exploitation a été réduit de 65.58 % à 18.46 % Il a été transport | 1.746 506 voyageurs de plus que l'année passé et le nombre des trains kilomètres parcourus augmenté de 139.056.
Les actionnaires de la Land investment Co sont convoqués en assemblée générale pour 10 janvier prochain. On parle d'un dividead de 46 piastres tarif par action.

L'assemblée des Upper Egypt Hotel, qui devait avoir lieu le 27 courant, a été rou voyée au 5 janvier prochain, faute de qoros requis pour délibérer. Al ir Ire du jour augmentation de capital et fixation de la fin de l'exercice au mois d'Avril.

Il s'est tenu vendredi dernier au Caire on assemblée générale offisieuse de la Société Wa ker & Meimarachi Ltd. en vue d'étudier question du transfert en Egypte du Conseil d'administration. div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Major P. T. F. Scoones, Royal Fusiliers, latterly serving with the 3rd Battalion at Middelburg, Cape Colony, and formerly with it at Cairo, has gone on retired pay. Major Swoopes spent Nearly twenty-two years in the Royal Fusiliers, having got his commission in them in May, 1885. He got his company in 1896, and the majority in 1901. He was adjutant of the 5th Battalion, at Hounslow, 1897-1903, including its tour of service on the blookboose lines in Orange Free State, Transvaal, and Cope Colony (Queen's medal with four clasps).
Second Lieutenant P. B. Wylie, 1st Battalion King's Own Scottish Borderers, has been promoted to lieutenant after three and a half years' service.
It is intimated that Geparat Bir C. M. Clarke, Bart., C.M.G., G.C.V.O., Governor and Com. mander-in-Chiot, Malta, is retained on the active list as a perdonorary on promotion to falk general rank.
Toe vacancy thus created has been filled by the promotion of Lieutenant General Sir Bin. don Blood, K B., a Clare gentleman with a distinguished career in India and South Africa.
The order for a draft of the 1st Battalion Royal Lonistilling Fusiliers to proceed from Belfast to Cairo to join the 2nd Battalion has been canceled.
Mock sympathy is expressed for Commodoro Stopford and Commander Bydovy Drury. Love, who were the victims, more or less, of circumstances in the late Portsmouth disturb
. The Admiralty from to have put little · weight on the front that the Commodore's

great popularity with the men greatly mobi. missed the disturbances of the first outbreak. Commodore Stopford was a splendid record of professional service, although never engaged in service, whilst Commander Deory-bowe was a middy of the Calliope in the bistorie burrionde at A pia, Samoa, and he was engaged op board the Hyacinth, flagebip of the East Indies Squadron, during which be commanded a battalion of bluejackets in the storming of Fort Illig. 1904.
After the New Year various ratings will be dispatched to the Mediterranean for distribution amongst the chips of that fleet.

SAILORS & SOLDIERS' INSTITUTE.

On Christmas Day, from 11 Am. until 19 p.m., the Sailors and Soldiers' lostitate was crowded with men from H.M.S. Carparvon, the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, the King's Royal Rifles, and others. A dinner of turkey, beef, plom padding, and mince pies, with dessert, was partaken of by 70 of these men and a number of civilian friends of the Institute, making a total of 111 at the tables.

On Boxing Day, the attendance again mounted op to several buadrede, and on both days there was much noise, merriment, music, singing and enjoyment without any alcoholic drink. To the evening of this day a magic lantern lecture on "A Tour round the World" was given by Rev. J. H. Scott (H.M.S. Cor. Darvon) to a full audience The boys of this ship, and tho-e from the R. Dublin Fusiliers and the K R Rifle 38, also met for a test on this occasion and competed for prizes which were the gifts of the following gentlemen: Meere. P. W. Carver. E. W. P. Foster, G. Fuster, W. Serjeant, C. Cowley. E Peel, Davie: Bryan & Co., L Putin & Co., Ltd, Egyptian Copetran tions, Ltd, Whitehead, Morris & Co., Ltd., and MacGregor & Co.

div.head: PARTICIPATION IN EGYPTIAN
div.p: CONTRACTS IN 1905.

The Austro-Hungarian Consulate Alexandria, reporting on the trade of Egypt in 1905, states that con 'racts with the Ministry of Finance in 1905 were particularly large supplies being seon red in many cases for a period of three years. Supplies for the Railway Department were also large ; the following is a statement of the participation by countries in the last three years:
Total 566,971

As will be seen from the above statement, more than half of the contract was secured by British firms, these being chiefly for locomotive, goods wagons, rails, signal apparatus, telegraph material, etc. Belgium supplied wagons, bridge and roofing materials, screws, and parts thereof; and France, oil, small machines, etc. Whereas in 1903 A 18tria Applied to the value of LE 48 000, in 1905 the supplies from this country were nil. The Council is of opinion that it Austrian manufacturers would pay more attention to this branch of nosino83, there is no reason why they should not become larger suppliers.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: VENICE
div.p: LIDO (Venice) VENICE
From Venice or Lido, charming trip on the lagoon, 12 min. by steamboat. CLIMATIC STATION AND SEA BATHS, WITH CHINESITHERAPIC INSTITUTE. Express between the station and Lido for the Hotels.
BAGNI LIDO (Venice)
The most important bathing station in Italy, Café-Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic Institute, Concerts daily. Frequented by the highest classes of society.
GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & Chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.
THE GRAND HOTEL, LIDO .

Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel) in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Lagune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address-SOCIETE BAGNI. LIDO, VENICE ITALY

div.head: SALSOMAGGIORE (Italy.)
div.p: A pleasantly situated village lying in the valley between Piacenza and Parma, rapidly becoming famous for its waters, which are very rich in bromine and iodine and the richest in the world in lithium, strontium, and ichthyol, and have been successfully used in the treatment of scrofula, rheumatism, tuberculous affections, ladies complaints, etc.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907
